ok is the device attached via USB or is it an internal device?

is it USB or is the wireless device in side the system?
how does the wireless connect to the system? does it stick out of the system, connected via USB or is the device not attached externally and is part of the system??

yes, you will need a connection to grab the driver with so use a wired connection
I mean a wireless usb key
ok then run:  lsusb  what is the 8 character Hex ID you have for the device

but the hex code is 0bda:8189
https://help.ubuntu.com/community/HardwareSupportComponentsWirelessNetworkCardsRealTek
you think my internal card is a realtek?
I think the realtek is the usb wireles, but I'm trying to fix the internal broadcom wireless card that came with this hp g62 laptop
its a realtek chip and now you know the model of the chip so yuou can find guides on how to make it run, strange its saying broadcom
you can always use the windows driver+ndisgtk if push comes to shove
I'm not sure if you mean the internal one or the one I'm using now
oh you have TWO wireless adapter, that makes more sense. ok the usb one uses a realtek chip and you can grab guides for that online
the internal one is a broadcom and should be usable once you use the broadcom how to
thanks very much!
I'm now not sure if my internal wireless card is actually broadcom. I just ran lscpi -vvnn  | grep 14e4 and it says "network controller: Broadcom" but no reference to a wireless card
I upgraded the driver via system/hardware drivers and now it works, thanks very much for your help!

i'd ask in #vbox
power off the vbox and go into the settings, there are shared folders there. It also shows how to map them to the OS
if you are using samba to share on the LAN you can use a bridged network connection and access the shares as if the virtual system was a real system of it'sown
can be easier although not as graceful, the #vbox guys will help. You will also find youtube vids detailing it too
is it not in the partner repo?
add the repo and you will be able to install it like any other app
memory test is a good start
hold shift at boot, select the memtest from the menu you see
if you have bad RAM try removing a stcik (after powering OFF) and retesting. This will help diagnose the bad stick

try: sudo apt-get --purge remove flashplugin-installer flashplugin-nonfree; sudo apt-get update; sudo apt-get install flashplugin-nonfree

boot with the device detached, log in and let the OS settle, plug it in and wait 10 seconds, then run:  dmesg | tail   may give clues
it will give clues as to what is going on
dmesg is all I can suggest. Once its been in a while you may see it if you run:  sudo lshw -C disk; sudo lshw -C drive
http://www.linux-on-laptops.com/toshiba.html
use software centre
sudo usermod -a -G sudo username
next time the user will log in they will be able to use sudo
you need to run it as someone who can ALREADY use sudo
if you wish, you can boot to root recovery console and run the command there :)

any user whom can run admin tasks needs to run the command as it changes the access of the user, users cannot add themselves to groups (unless there is a group password and the user has been given the password)
so root or any other user in the sudo group can do i
if you run:  whoami   does it say 'root'?
